subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment 2  - RESULTS!
author: SnowfireL@aol.com
full_text:
----------MB_8CCF58C42EC91E2_37D0_6CEB_Webmail-d111.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"

 RJ. David insists you had an ink pen there, and "he changed it."

 



---=
--Original Message-----
From: rasterer <rasterer@...>
To: EVP-I=
TC@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Mon, Jul 19, 2010 2:39 pm
Subject: [EVP-ITC] Exper=
iment 2  - RESULTS!

          =C2=A0                                  Than=
ks to everyone who participated in Experiment 2.
 
 On Friday, 7/16/2010 I =
placed an object on top of my computer monitor, right in front of me, and l=
eft it there until noon Denver time on Monday, 7/19/2010.   This experiment=
 asked for participants to determine what that object was. Vague or partial=
 answers would not be counted (for example, just giving a color, shape, siz=
e,  what it's made of, etc): we're looking for what it is. Answers anyone r=
eveals after noon Denver time Monday won't count.  Participants can use the=
ir ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or any other means they chose.  
 
 In order=
 to keep me honest, I took a picture of the object at the start of the expe=
riment and loaded it to the Files section (RJ folder) of this group.  The i=
dea with this file is that you could download it at the beginning of the ex=
periment and 'keep it safe' on your computer. Then at the end of the experi=
ment, I would post the password so you can reveal the contents of the file.=
 That way, you were in control of the original image during the entire time=
, not me.  
 
 Passworded pdf: http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/f=
iles/RJ/RJ20100716.pdf
 
 The password for that file is: 2plus2isFour
 Inst=
ructions, if you need them for the other files, are also in that RJ folder.=

 
 So to the results:
 
 Number of participants: 6
 Total tries: 29
 Ambig=
uous answers: 0
 Correct answers: 0
 
 Object: Chair
 Object picture: http:=
//tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100716.jpg
 
 As a littl=
e side experiment, on Monday I also asked if anyone had gotten any answers =
that might indicate an article of clothing (though I did not say why I was =
asking).   One theory is that the human operator can be influenced by thing=
s they already know or suspect, and so interpret audio with their own perso=
nal 'educated guesses', that would differ from what they would hear had the=
y not known those things.  This side experiment did indicate some support f=
or that theory, since before I mentioned 'articles of clothing', no one inc=
luded an article of clothing in their results.  But after I mentioned it, s=
everal reports of clothing began to appear.  I did not add these tries to t=
he results above.
 
 If anyone has any observations, comments, or ideas for=
 improvement, let me know. Again, thanks to everyone who participated in th=
is experiment.
 
 
      
                 
   
       
  


----------MB_8CCF58C42EC91E2_37D0_6CEB_Webmail-d111.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html; charset="utf-8"

id insists you had an ink pen there, and "he changed it."<br>
</div>

 <br>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

From: rastere=

Subject: [EVP-ITC] Experiment 2  - RESULTS!<br>

<div id=3D"AOLMsgPart_2_bcaa7c47-6f3b-419b-827e-7aa6012117aa">       =

g" style=3D"position: relative;">

<div id=3D"ygrp-text">                     
<div>Thanks to eve=
ryone who participated in Experiment 2.<br>
 <br>
 On Friday, 7/16/2010 I p=
laced an object on top of my computer monitor, right in front of me, and le=
ft it there until noon Denver time on Monday, 7/19/2010.   This experiment =
asked for participants to determine what that object was. Vague or partial =
answers would not be counted (for example, just giving a color, shape, size=
,  what it's made of, etc): we're looking for what it is. Answers anyone re=
veals after noon Denver time Monday won't count.  Participants can use thei=
r ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or any other means they chose.  <br>
 <br>
 I=
n order to keep me honest, I took a picture of the object at the start of t=
he experiment and loaded it to the Files section (RJ folder) of this group.=
  The idea with this file is that you could download it at the beginning of=
 the experiment and 'keep it safe' on your computer. Then at the end of the=
 experiment, I would post the password so you can reveal the contents of th=
e file. That way, you were in control of the original image during the enti=
re time, not me.  <br>
 <br>
 Passworded pdf: <a target=3D"_blank" href=3D"=
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100716.pdf">http://=
tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100716.pdf</a><br>
 <br>
 =
The password for that file is: 2plus2isFour<br>
 Instructions, if you need =
them for the other files, are also in that RJ folder.<br>
 <br>
 So to the =
results:<br>
 <br>
 Number of participants: 6<br>
 Total tries: 29<br>
 Amb=
iguous answers: 0<br>
 Correct answers: 0<br>
 <br>
 Object: Chair<br>
 Obj=
ect picture: <a target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/grou=
p/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ20100716.jpg">http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-I=
TC/files/RJ/RJ20100716.jpg</a><br>
 <br>
 As a little side experiment, on M=
onday I also asked if anyone had gotten any answers that might indicate an =
article of clothing (though I did not say why I was asking).   One theory i=
s that the human operator can be influenced by things they already know or =
suspect, and so interpret audio with their own personal 'educated guesses',=
 that would differ from what they would hear had they not known those thing=
s.  This side experiment did indicate some support for that theory, since b=
efore I mentioned 'articles of clothing', no one included an article of clo=
thing in their results.  But after I mentioned it, several reports of cloth=
ing began to appear.  I did not add these tries to the results above.<br>
 =
<br>
 If anyone has any observations, comments, or ideas for improvement, l=
et me know. Again, thanks to everyone who participated in this experiment.<=
br>
 <br>
 </div>
      </div>
